II: <u>The Circulatory system of the Terebratulidae <\u>
Considerable differences of opinion have 
prevailed among comparative anatomists 
as to the nature and arrangement of the
vascular system in the Brachiopoda -
A pair of organs, one on each side of the 
body, have been recognised as hearts 
since the time of Cuvier - who declared 
these hearts in Lingula to be aortic 
receiving the blood from the mantle &
pouring it into the body - the principal 
arterial trunks being distributed into 
that glandular mass which Cuvier called 
ovary, but which is now known to be 
the genital glands of either sex.
Prof. Owen in his first memoir follows 
Cuviers interpretation, stating that in 
orbicula the pallial veins terminate 
in the heart - from which arterial
